Then we can write the ZKP inputs as

𝐀~=10−d​𝐒𝐢𝐠𝐧​(𝐀)∘𝐀~+wherea~s,t+∈ℕ0​.formulae-sequence~𝐀superscript10𝑑𝐒𝐢𝐠𝐧𝐀superscript~𝐀wheresubscriptsuperscript~𝑎𝑠𝑡subscriptℕ0.\displaystyle\tilde{\mathbf{A}}=10^{-d}\,\mathbf{{Sign}(A)}\circ\mathbf{\tilde{A}^{+}}\qquad\text{where}\quad\tilde{a}^{+}_{s,t}\in\mathbb{N}_{0}\text{.} (8)

Moreover, ∥𝐀~−𝐀∥≤c⋅10−ddelimited-∥∥~𝐀𝐀⋅𝑐superscript10𝑑\lVert\mathbf{\tilde{A}}-\mathbf{A}\rVert\leq c\cdot 10^{-d}, where c𝑐c depends on the choice of matrix norm. For example. if we use the maximum norm, c𝑐c can be 0.50.50.5 times the number of columns of A𝐴A.

After this transformation, uisubscript𝑢𝑖u_{i} can compute the ZKP. However, as constructing proofs is computationally expensive, designing the ZKP generation requires specific consideration and optimizations. For better readability, we will refrain from using client indices i𝑖i in the following description. First, to make sure that the client’s input data is standardized, we introduce an upper bound for the mean μ𝜇\mu. Note that since circom does not allow for non-integer divisions, we apply the upper bound controlling μ𝜇\mu to the sum of all elements in Y𝑌Y and X1,…​Xksubscript𝑋1…subscript𝑋𝑘X_{1},\ldots X_{k}:

μXj⋅n=∑l=1,…​nxj,l≤εμμY⋅n=∑l=1,…​nyl≤εμ∀j∈{1,…,k}.⋅subscript𝜇subscript𝑋𝑗𝑛subscript𝑙1…𝑛subscript𝑥𝑗𝑙⋅subscript𝜀𝜇subscript𝜇𝑌𝑛subscript𝑙1…𝑛subscript𝑦𝑙subscript𝜀𝜇for-all𝑗1…𝑘\displaystyle\begin{split}\mu_{X_{j}}\cdot n=\sum\limits_{l=1,\ldots n}x_{j,l}&\leq\varepsilon_{\mu}\\ \mu_{Y}\cdot n=\sum\limits_{l=1,\ldots n}y_{l}&\leq\varepsilon_{\mu}\end{split}~{}\quad~{}\forall~{}j\in\{1,\ldots,k\}. (9)

Similarly, we regulate the data set’s variance σ2superscript𝜎2\sigma^{2} by applying an upper bound to the squared sums:

σXj2⋅n=∑l=1,…​n(xj,l−μ)2≤εσσY2⋅n=∑l=1,…​n(yl−μ)2≤εσ∀j∈{1,…,k}.⋅superscriptsubscript𝜎subscript𝑋𝑗2𝑛subscript𝑙1…𝑛superscriptsubscript𝑥𝑗𝑙𝜇2⋅subscript𝜀𝜎superscriptsubscript𝜎𝑌2𝑛subscript𝑙1…𝑛superscriptsubscript𝑦𝑙𝜇2subscript𝜀𝜎for-all𝑗1…𝑘\displaystyle\begin{split}\sigma_{X_{j}}^{2}\cdot n=\sum\limits_{l=1,\ldots n}\left(x_{j,l}-\mu\right)^{2}&\leq\varepsilon_{\sigma}\\ \sigma_{Y}^{2}\cdot n=\sum\limits_{l=1,\ldots n}\left(y_{l}-\mu\right)^{2}&\leq\varepsilon_{\sigma}\end{split}~{}\quad~{}\forall~{}j\in\{1,\ldots,k\}. (10)

Hence, εμsubscript𝜀𝜇\varepsilon_{\mu} and εσsubscript𝜀𝜎\varepsilon_{\sigma} must be set with respect to n𝑛n.

Recalling (6), our initial attempt was to compute the inverse (𝐗⊺​𝐗)−1superscriptsuperscript𝐗⊺𝐗1(\mathbf{X}^{\intercal}\mathbf{X})^{-1} within a circuit of the respective ZKP by introducing two integers, a denominator and a numerator, per input value. This procedure would allow us to calculate (𝐗⊺​𝐗)−1superscriptsuperscript𝐗⊺𝐗1(\mathbf{X}^{\intercal}\mathbf{X})^{-1} in the circuit (as divisions leading to non-integer values can be replaced by multiplications) without rounding errors (given the input values are precise). However, the approach turned out to have one significant shortcoming: Computing (𝐗⊺​𝐗)−1superscriptsuperscript𝐗⊺𝐗1(\mathbf{X}^{\intercal}\mathbf{X})^{-1} within a circuit using Gaussian elimination quickly results in overflow (i.e., a numerator or denominator can quickly get larger than the size of the prime field). Finding common denominators often requires multiplying all denominators repeatedly. For example, already computing the inverse of (𝐗⊺​𝐗)5×5superscriptsuperscript𝐗⊺𝐗55(\mathbf{X}^{\intercal}\mathbf{X})^{5\times 5} matrices with d=5𝑑5d=5 can cause an overflow (in general, this will depend on the choice of d𝑑d and k𝑘k, but 2k⋅d⋅superscript2𝑘𝑑2^{k}\cdot d will probably be larger than 787878 in many practical applications). On the other hand, reducing fractions or rounding (using range proofs) before overflow would add further complexity in the Gaussian elimination algorithm. Besides, more complex operations demanded by more sophisticated ML algorithms would require to hand-craft a fast numerical solver, so the method does not generalize well. Eventually, this approach would hardly scale to more complicated optimization algorithms.

As matrix inversion inside the circuit or inverting within circom’s prime field is expensive, we decided to follow the approach of Wu et al. [62] to solve the problem by letting clients calculate and provide an inverse 𝐙≈(𝐗⊺​𝐗)−1𝐙superscriptsuperscript𝐗⊺𝐗1\mathbf{Z}\approx(\mathbf{X}^{\intercal}\mathbf{X})^{-1} outside the circuit through a standard solver such as typical matrix inversion tools in Javascript, Python, or MATLAB. We then give this inverse as private input to the circuit (again complying with the above-described conversion to non-negative integer entries). However, due to the finite precision of the matrix inversion, we cannot assume that equality holds. Thus, we apply a slightly different method and only prove the proximity of the calculated inverse to the true inverse. To do so, we check the approximation error of the provided numerical inverse using the following range constraint:

∥(𝐗⊺​𝐗)​𝐙−(𝐗⊺​𝐗)​(𝐗⊺​𝐗)−1∥=∥(𝐗⊺​𝐗)​𝐙−𝟙∥≤εinverse<1.delimited-∥∥superscript𝐗⊺𝐗𝐙superscript𝐗⊺𝐗superscriptsuperscript𝐗⊺𝐗1delimited-∥∥superscript𝐗⊺𝐗𝐙1subscript𝜀inverse1\displaystyle\lVert(\mathbf{X}^{\intercal}\mathbf{X})\mathbf{Z}-(\mathbf{X}^{\intercal}\mathbf{X})(\mathbf{X}^{\intercal}\mathbf{X})^{-1}\rVert=\lVert(\mathbf{X}^{\intercal}\mathbf{X})\mathbf{Z}-\mathbbm{1}\rVert\leq\varepsilon_{\mathrm{inverse}}<1. (11)

As matrix norm, the maximum norm is a convenient choice, i.e., the inequality can be checked index-wise (respecting k𝑘k). Through this bound, we can both control for the effect that the replacement of (𝐗⊺​𝐗)−1superscriptsuperscript𝐗⊺𝐗1(\mathbf{X}^{\intercal}\mathbf{X})^{-1} with its approximation 𝐙𝐙\mathbf{Z} has and ensure that the system remains protected against malicious client attacks. To do so, we estimate an upper bound for the approximation effects on the distance from w𝑤w to w~~𝑤\tilde{w}, with the latter being calculated based on 𝐙𝐙\mathbf{Z}, via

∥w−w~∥≤∥(𝐗⊺​𝐗)−1​𝐗⊺​Y−𝐙𝐗⊺​Y∥≤∥(𝐗⊺​𝐗)−1−𝐙∥⋅∥𝐗⊺​Y∥≤εw,delimited-∥∥𝑤~𝑤delimited-∥∥superscriptsuperscript𝐗⊺𝐗1superscript𝐗⊺𝑌superscript𝐙𝐗⊺𝑌⋅delimited-∥∥superscriptsuperscript𝐗⊺𝐗1𝐙delimited-∥∥superscript𝐗⊺𝑌subscript𝜀𝑤\displaystyle\begin{split}\lVert w-\tilde{w}\rVert&\leq\lVert(\mathbf{X}^{\intercal}\mathbf{X})^{-1}\mathbf{X}^{\intercal}Y-\mathbf{Z}\mathbf{X}^{\intercal}Y\rVert\\ &\leq\lVert(\mathbf{X}^{\intercal}\mathbf{X})^{-1}-\mathbf{Z}\rVert\cdot\lVert\mathbf{X}^{\intercal}Y\rVert\leq\varepsilon_{w},\end{split} (12)

where we use the submultiplicativity of ∥⋅∥delimited-∥∥⋅\lVert\,\cdot\,\rVert. Even though all entries of 𝐗⊺superscript𝐗⊺\mathbf{X}^{\intercal} and Y𝑌Y are normalized, i.e., X1,…,Xk,Ysubscript𝑋1…subscript𝑋𝑘𝑌X_{1},\ldots,X_{k},Y have expectation value μ=0𝜇0\mu=0 and the standard deviation σ=1𝜎1\sigma=1, ∥𝐗⊺​Y∥delimited-∥∥superscript𝐗⊺𝑌\lVert\mathbf{X}^{\intercal}Y\rVert might still yield large entries. Thus, to control the error ∥w−w′∥delimited-∥∥𝑤superscript𝑤′\lVert w-w^{\prime}\rVert between the true weights and the client’s approximative result, we desire upper bounds for both ∥(𝐗⊺​𝐗)−1−𝐙∥delimited-∥∥superscriptsuperscript𝐗⊺𝐗1𝐙\lVert(\mathbf{X}^{\intercal}\mathbf{X})^{-1}-\mathbf{Z}\rVert and ∥𝐗⊺​Y∥delimited-∥∥superscript𝐗⊺𝑌\lVert\mathbf{X}^{\intercal}Y\rVert.

First, we introduce a simple range proof to ensure that ∥𝐗⊺​Y∥delimited-∥∥superscript𝐗⊺𝑌\lVert\mathbf{X}^{\intercal}Y\rVert is bounded:

∥𝐗⊺​Y∥≤ϑ𝐗⊺​Ywhereϑ𝐗⊺​Y≡ϑ𝐗⊺​Y​(k,d)​.formulae-sequencedelimited-∥∥superscript𝐗⊺𝑌subscriptitalic-ϑsuperscript𝐗⊺𝑌wheresubscriptitalic-ϑsuperscript𝐗⊺𝑌subscriptitalic-ϑsuperscript𝐗⊺𝑌𝑘𝑑.\displaystyle\lVert\mathbf{X}^{\intercal}Y\rVert\leq\vartheta_{\mathbf{X}^{\intercal}Y}\quad\mathrm{where}\quad\vartheta_{\mathbf{X}^{\intercal}Y}\equiv\vartheta_{\mathbf{X}^{\intercal}Y}\left(k,d\right)\text{.} (13)

In general, the probability that ∥𝐗⊺​Y∥delimited-∥∥superscript𝐗⊺𝑌\lVert\mathbf{X}^{\intercal}Y\rVert is large is very small as the normal distribution decays fast; if by coincidence a single value is big, d𝑑d might need to be adjusted to increase the accuracy of rounded inputs.

Second, we recall that the true inverse can essentially be replaced by the approximative inverse as long as the approximate inverse is bounded [67]. More precisely, given any matrix norm ∥⋅∥delimited-∥∥⋅\lVert\,\cdot\,\rVert, a square nonsingular matrix 𝐀𝐀\mathbf{A} and its approximate inverse 𝐙𝐙\mathbf{Z} such that ∥𝐀𝐙−𝟙∥≤εrange<1delimited-∥∥𝐀𝐙1subscript𝜀range1\lVert\mathbf{A}\mathbf{Z}-\mathbbm{1}\rVert\leq\varepsilon_{\mathrm{range}}<1, the bound

∥𝐀−1−𝐙∥≤∥𝐙∥×∥𝐀𝐙−𝟙∥1−∥𝐀𝐙−𝟙∥delimited-∥∥superscript𝐀1𝐙delimited-∥∥𝐙delimited-∥∥𝐀𝐙11delimited-∥∥𝐀𝐙1\displaystyle\lVert\mathbf{A}^{-1}-\mathbf{Z}\rVert\leq\frac{\lVert\mathbf{Z}\rVert\times\lVert\mathbf{A}\mathbf{Z}-\mathbbm{1}\rVert}{1-\lVert\mathbf{A}\mathbf{Z}-\mathbbm{1}\rVert} (14)

holds. However, it is not clear that 𝐗⊺​𝐗superscript𝐗⊺𝐗\mathbf{X}^{\intercal}\mathbf{X} is non-singular, and checking this inside the circuit, e.g., through computing the determinant, would become expensive already for moderate k𝑘k. Fortunately, we can relax the assumption by reconsidering the argument in the derivation of the result in Newman [67]: Provided the candidate for the approximate inverse satisfies ∥𝐑∥<1delimited-∥∥𝐑1\lVert\mathbf{R}\rVert<1 for 𝐑:=𝐀𝐙−𝟙assign𝐑𝐀𝐙1\mathbf{R}:=\mathbf{A}\mathbf{Z}-\mathbbm{1}, then the Neumann-series 𝟙+𝐑+𝐑2+…1𝐑superscript𝐑2…\mathbbm{1}+\mathbf{R}+\mathbf{R}^{2}+\ldots converges. Consequently, using the argument in the paper,

𝐀𝐙⋅(𝟙+𝐑+𝐑2+…)=(𝟙−𝐑)⋅(𝟙+𝐑+𝐑2+…)=𝟙.⋅𝐀𝐙1𝐑superscript𝐑2…⋅1𝐑1𝐑superscript𝐑2…1\displaystyle\mathbf{A}\mathbf{Z}\cdot(\mathbbm{1}+\mathbf{R}+\mathbf{R}^{2}+\ldots)=(\mathbbm{1}-\mathbf{R})\cdot(\mathbbm{1}+\mathbf{R}+\mathbf{R}^{2}+\ldots)=\mathbbm{1}. (15)

It follows that 𝐙​(𝟙+𝐑+𝐑2+…)𝐙1𝐑superscript𝐑2…\mathbf{Z}(\mathbbm{1}+\mathbf{R}+\mathbf{R}^{2}+\ldots) is a right-inverse of the quadratic matrix 𝐀𝐀\mathbf{A} and hence its unique (left- and right-) inverse, i.e., 𝐀𝐀\mathbf{A} is non-singular. In particular, we learn that if 𝐀𝐀\mathbf{A} was non-singular, we could not find an approximate inverse that satisfies (11). Applied to 𝐀:=𝐗⊺​𝐗assign𝐀superscript𝐗⊺𝐗\mathbf{A}:=\mathbf{X}^{\intercal}\mathbf{X}, our circuit already implicitly guarantees that 𝐗⊺​𝐗superscript𝐗⊺𝐗\mathbf{X}^{\intercal}\mathbf{X} is invertible through checking (11), and (14) yields

∥(𝐗⊺​𝐗)−1−𝐙∥≤∥𝐙∥×∥(𝐗⊺​𝐗)​𝐙−𝟙∥1−∥(𝐗⊺​𝐗)​𝐙−𝟙∥≤ϑ𝐙⋅εinverse​,delimited-∥∥superscriptsuperscript𝐗⊺𝐗1𝐙delimited-∥∥𝐙delimited-∥∥superscript𝐗⊺𝐗𝐙11delimited-∥∥superscript𝐗⊺𝐗𝐙1⋅subscriptitalic-ϑ𝐙subscript𝜀inverse,\displaystyle\lVert(\mathbf{X}^{\intercal}\mathbf{X})^{-1}-\mathbf{Z}\rVert\leq\frac{\lVert\mathbf{Z}\rVert\times\lVert(\mathbf{X}^{\intercal}\mathbf{X})\mathbf{Z}-\mathbbm{1}\rVert}{1-\lVert(\mathbf{X}^{\intercal}\mathbf{X})\mathbf{Z}-\mathbbm{1}\rVert}\leq\vartheta_{\mathbf{Z}}\cdot\varepsilon_{\mathrm{inverse}}~{}\text{,} (16)

where ∥𝐙∥≤ϑ𝐙\quad\rVert\mathbf{Z}\lVert~{}\leq~{}\vartheta_{\mathbf{Z}} and ϑ𝐙≡ϑ𝐙​(k,d)subscriptitalic-ϑ𝐙subscriptitalic-ϑ𝐙𝑘𝑑\vartheta_{\mathbf{Z}}\equiv\vartheta_{\mathbf{Z}}\left(k,d\right).

Before uploading w𝑤w to the EVM storage, clients must perturb their weight by adding Laplacian LDP-noise (recall (4) and (5)) to avoid deep leakage [19]:

w′superscript𝑤′\displaystyle w^{\prime} =w+q,absent𝑤𝑞\displaystyle=w+q,\qquad q∼ℒ​(0,λ),q∈ℝkformulae-sequencesimilar-to𝑞ℒ0𝜆𝑞superscriptℝ𝑘\displaystyle q\sim\mathcal{L}(0,\lambda),~{}q\in\mathbb{R}^{k} (17)
λ𝜆\displaystyle\lambda =Δϵ=1ϵ​(max⁡βi,j−min⁡βi,j)absentΔitalic-ϵ1italic-ϵsubscript𝛽𝑖𝑗subscript𝛽𝑖𝑗\displaystyle=\frac{\Delta}{\epsilon}=\frac{1}{\epsilon}\left(\max\beta_{i,j}-\min\beta_{i,j}\right)\qquad i∈{1,…,|I|},j∈{0,…,k}.formulae-sequence𝑖1…𝐼𝑗0…𝑘\displaystyle i\in\{1,\dots,\lvert I\rvert\},~{}j\in\{0,\dots,k\}. (18)

Note that every entry in q𝑞q is drawn separately, following ℒ​(0,λ)ℒ0𝜆\mathcal{L}(0,\lambda). Moreover, since we perturb client weights that will be aggregated, we must set the LDP security parameter ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon globally. As no fellow βi,jsubscript𝛽𝑖𝑗\beta_{i,j} will be available to any client before uploading the client’s own w𝑤w, we must set an estimation for ΔΔ\Delta globally. Recalling that all w𝑤w are computed based on normalized data, we know that β0,…,βk∈[-​1;1]subscript𝛽0…subscript𝛽𝑘-11\beta_{0},\dots,\beta_{k}\in[\text{-}1;1] holds. Therefore, we set Δ=2⋅10dΔ⋅2superscript10𝑑\Delta=2\cdot 10^{d} as a proxy. Moreover, to generate πwsuperscript𝜋𝑤\pi^{w}, we must ensure that we can reproduce every entry in q𝑞q while keeping its choice random. Achieving this requires a twofold approach.

First, since circom does not have tools to compute a Laplace-distributed random variable directly, we discretize ℒ​(0,λ)ℒ0𝜆\mathcal{L}(0,\lambda), introducing a variable dℒ=10xsubscript𝑑ℒsuperscript10𝑥d_{\mathcal{L}}=10^{x} with x∈ℕ𝑥ℕx\in\mathbb{N} that defines the interval of a discrete distribution 𝒟​ℒ​(0,λ)𝒟ℒ0𝜆\mathcal{DL}(0,\lambda) of ℒ​(0,λ)ℒ0𝜆\mathcal{L}(0,\lambda) (i.e., 𝒟​ℒ𝒟ℒ\mathcal{DL}’s accuracy). We then construct a vector L∈ℝdℒ−1𝐿superscriptℝsubscript𝑑ℒ1L\in\mathbb{R}^{d_{\mathcal{L}}-1} whose entries are given by the inverse cumulative distribution function of 𝒟​ℒ​(0,λ)𝒟ℒ0𝜆\mathcal{DL}(0,\lambda):

L​(p):=−λ​sgn​(p−12)​ln​(1−2​|p−12|),p={1,…,dℒ−1}.formulae-sequenceassign𝐿𝑝𝜆sgn𝑝12ln12𝑝12𝑝1…subscript𝑑ℒ1\displaystyle L(p):=-\lambda~{}\text{sgn}\left(p-\frac{1}{2}\right)~{}\text{ln}\left(1-2\Big{|}p-\frac{1}{2}\Big{|}\right),\quad p=\{1,\dots,d_{\mathcal{L}}-1\}. (19)

The finite nature of machines leads to some form of discretization of distributions, which makes DP mechanisms generally vulnerable to attacks [68]. Therefore, there is a research stream dedicated to exploring the effects of discretization on LDP (e.g., Balcer and Vadhan (2019), Canonne et al. (2021)). However, in our system, the parameters are currently set in a way that the limitation through dℒsubscript𝑑ℒd_{\mathcal{L}} will be stricter than that of the precision typically achieved in computer programs.

Second, we draw the underlying randomness p𝑝p from the random oracle hjsubscriptℎ𝑗h_{j} that results from hashing a solid source of entropy like the current block hash of the blockchain and the entry of Y𝑌Y that corresponds to the βjsubscript𝛽𝑗\beta_{j} that is being perturbed:

hj=H​(current block hash|yj),j={0,…,k}.formulae-sequencesubscriptℎ𝑗𝐻conditionalcurrent block hashsubscript𝑦𝑗𝑗0…𝑘\displaystyle h_{j}=H\left(\text{current block hash}~{}|~{}y_{j}\right),\quad j=\{0,\dots,k\}. (20)

So, for example, when perturbing β0′=β0+q0subscriptsuperscript𝛽′0subscript𝛽0subscript𝑞0\beta^{\prime}_{0}=\beta_{0}+q_{0}, the corresponding entry of Y𝑌Y is y0subscript𝑦0y_{0}. The resulting hjsubscriptℎ𝑗h_{j} is a 256-bit number. We derive every p𝑝p by computing

p=hj​mod​dℒ,j={0,…,k}​.formulae-sequence𝑝subscriptℎ𝑗modsubscript𝑑ℒ𝑗0…𝑘.\displaystyle p=h_{j}~{}\text{mod}~{}d_{\mathcal{L}},\quad j=\{0,\dots,k\}\text{.} (21)

The noise that results from a particular value of p𝑝p, as well as its distribution (which is close to the true Laplace distribution with λ=1𝜆1\lambda=1, is illustrated in Figures 1(a) and 1(b)). Essentially, we generate verifiable randomness (similar as used, e.g., in Algorand for electing block producers) deterministically in the circuit by combining entropy from the blockchain and from the training data that was the client previously committed to. This approach ensures that clients cannot influence their LDP-noise q𝑞q whilst fellow clients cannot reproduce the q𝑞q (which would allow them to leak the ‘unperturbed’ w𝑤w) and verify that the noise was produced purely at random: As the client could not predict the entropy taken from the blockchain at the time of committing to Disubscript𝐷𝑖D_{i}, and consequently not try different values for Y𝑌Y that yield the desired noise. Additionally, by inputting L𝐿L, πwsubscript𝜋𝑤\pi_{w}’s circuits can verify p𝑝p.

Now the clients are ready to generate their ZKPs that allows for verifying the validity of the clients’ local computations of w′superscript𝑤′w^{\prime}. Given the proposed architecture, the ZKP πw​(a,b)superscript𝜋𝑤𝑎𝑏\pi^{w}(a,b) with statement a𝑎a and witness b𝑏b that proves that u𝑢u has truthfully calculated w′superscript𝑤′w^{\prime} has the following characteristic:

πw​((w′,r​t𝐃,εμ,εσ,εw′,εinverse,ϑ𝐗⊺​Y,ϑ𝐙),(𝐃,𝐙)).superscript𝜋𝑤superscript𝑤′𝑟superscript𝑡𝐃subscript𝜀𝜇subscript𝜀𝜎subscript𝜀superscript𝑤′subscript𝜀inversesubscriptitalic-ϑsuperscript𝐗⊺𝑌subscriptitalic-ϑ𝐙𝐃𝐙\displaystyle\pi^{w}\left(\left(w^{\prime},rt^{\mathbf{D}},\varepsilon_{\mu},\varepsilon_{\sigma},\varepsilon_{w^{\prime}},\varepsilon_{\mathrm{inverse}},\vartheta_{\mathbf{X}^{\intercal}Y},\vartheta_{\mathbf{Z}}\right),\left(\mathbf{D},\mathbf{Z}\right)\right). (22)

Besides the above-described range proofs and computation checks, πwsuperscript𝜋𝑤\pi^{w} ensures a globally set range εw′subscript𝜀superscript𝑤′\varepsilon_{w^{\prime}} for the submitted w′superscript𝑤′w^{\prime}:

∥w′−w~′∥≤εw′.delimited-∥∥superscript𝑤′superscript~𝑤′subscript𝜀superscript𝑤′\displaystyle\lVert w^{\prime}-\tilde{w}^{\prime}\rVert\leq\varepsilon_{w^{\prime}}.

Please refer to Section 3.2 for a detailed description of how we implement πwsuperscript𝜋𝑤\pi^{w}.

Using a smart contract and through snarkjs’ export solidityverifier command, clients can, subsequently to compiling the circuit and generating the proof, upload their w′superscript𝑤′w^{\prime} to the EVM. The smart contract verifies the proof and, if valid, uploads the client’s w′superscript𝑤′w^{\prime}.

3.1.2 Model Aggregation

For every successfully uploaded wi′subscriptsuperscript𝑤′𝑖w^{\prime}_{i}, the smart contract Clients updates wgsubscript𝑤gw_{\mathrm{g}} by aggregating all weights that have been submitted to the smart contract so far using FedAvg. For a globally constant sample size n𝑛n in a LR setting, the respective aggregation formula equals

wg=∑i=1|I|wi|I|≈∑i=1|I|wi′|I|=wg′​,subscript𝑤gsuperscriptsubscript𝑖1𝐼subscript𝑤𝑖𝐼superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝐼subscriptsuperscript𝑤′𝑖𝐼subscriptsuperscript𝑤′g,\displaystyle\begin{split}w_{\mathrm{g}}=\frac{\sum_{i=1}^{\lvert I\rvert}w_{i}}{\lvert I\rvert}\approx\frac{\sum_{i=1}^{\lvert I\rvert}w^{\prime}_{i}}{\lvert I\rvert}=w^{\prime}_{\mathrm{g}}\text{,}\end{split} (23)

depending on ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon and |I|𝐼\lvert I\rvert. Heuristically, the noise is i.i.d. with expectation value 00 and finite variance 2​λ22superscript𝜆22\lambda^{2}, so by the law of large numbers, the probability that wgsubscript𝑤gw_{\mathrm{g}} differs significantly from wg′subscriptsuperscript𝑤′gw^{\prime}_{\mathrm{g}} is small (in fact, the deviation is approximately normally distributed with standard deviation 2​λ2|I|2superscript𝜆2𝐼\tfrac{2\lambda^{2}}{\sqrt{|I|}}.

3.1.3 Compute and Prove Model Cost

After submitting and proving their LDP-weights w′superscript𝑤′w^{\prime}, clients test their unperturbed w𝑤w on a global and public data set 𝐃test=(𝐗test​Ytest)=(Xtest,0​Xtest,1​…​Xtest,k​Ytest)∈ℝntest×(k+2)subscript𝐃testsubscript𝐗testsubscript𝑌testsubscript𝑋test0subscript𝑋test1…subscript𝑋test𝑘subscript𝑌testsuperscriptℝsubscript𝑛test𝑘2\mathbf{D}_{\textrm{test}}=(\mathbf{X}_{\mathrm{test}}~{}Y_{\mathrm{test}})=(X_{\mathrm{test},0}~{}X_{\mathrm{test},1}~{}\ldots~{}X_{\mathrm{test},k}~{}Y_{\mathrm{test}})\in\mathbb{R}^{n_{\mathrm{test}}\times(k+2)} with Xtest=(1,…,1)⊺subscript𝑋testsuperscript1…1⊺X_{\mathrm{test}}=(1,...,1)^{\intercal}, distributed via a public channel (e.g., a cloud provider). Clients have to prove that they computed their model cost c𝑐c truthfully based on 𝐃testsubscript𝐃test\mathbf{D}_{\textrm{test}} and using their w𝑤w by constructing a ZKP πcsuperscript𝜋𝑐\pi^{c} with the following characteristic.

πc​((c,r​t𝐃,r​t𝐃test,εw),(𝐃,𝐙,w)).superscript𝜋𝑐𝑐𝑟superscript𝑡𝐃𝑟superscript𝑡subscript𝐃testsubscript𝜀𝑤𝐃𝐙𝑤\displaystyle\pi^{c}\left(\left(c,rt^{\mathbf{D}},rt^{\mathbf{D}_{\mathrm{test}}},\varepsilon_{w}\right),\left(\mathbf{D},\mathbf{Z},w\right)\right). (24)

πcsuperscript𝜋𝑐\pi^{c} ensures that clients used the private input w𝑤w (i.e., their true and unperturbed weight) to compute c𝑐c by first reproducing w~~𝑤\tilde{w} in a circuit of the ZKP and performing the range proof (recall (12))

∥w−w~∥≤εw.delimited-∥∥𝑤~𝑤subscript𝜀𝑤.\displaystyle\lVert w-\tilde{w}\rVert\leq\varepsilon_{w}\quad\text{.}

Note that the SC Clients requires that clients have uploaded a valid w𝑤w prior to submitting and proving c𝑐c, such that the standardization of r​t𝐃𝑟superscript𝑡𝐃rt^{\mathbf{D}} as well as the effects of approximating ∥𝐗⊺​Y∥delimited-∥∥superscript𝐗⊺𝑌\lVert\mathbf{X}^{\intercal}Y\rVert through ∥𝐙∥delimited-∥∥𝐙\lVert\mathbf{Z}\rVert are already controlled by πwsuperscript𝜋𝑤\pi^{w}. Then, as w𝑤w is a private input to πcsuperscript𝜋𝑐\pi^{c}, we can compute c~~𝑐\tilde{c} in a circuit of πcsuperscript𝜋𝑐\pi^{c} and make sure that

c~=(Ytest−Y^test)⊺​(Ytest−Y^test)=c~𝑐superscriptsubscript𝑌testsubscript^𝑌test⊺subscript𝑌testsubscript^𝑌test𝑐\displaystyle\tilde{c}=\big{(}Y_{\mathrm{test}}-\hat{Y}_{\mathrm{test}}\big{)}^{\intercal}\big{(}Y_{\mathrm{test}}-\hat{Y}_{\mathrm{test}}\big{)}=c (25)

with Y^test=𝐗test⋅wsubscript^𝑌test⋅subscript𝐗test𝑤\hat{Y}_{\mathrm{test}}=\mathbf{X}_{\mathrm{test}}\,\cdot\,w holds.

Second, by including r​t𝐃test𝑟superscript𝑡subscript𝐃testrt^{\mathbf{D}_{\mathrm{test}}} as a statement, πcsuperscript𝜋𝑐\pi^{c} can compute the respective Merkle tree on the test data set 𝐃testsuperscript𝐃test\mathbf{D}^{\mathrm{test}} and require that the resulting root r​t~𝐃testsuperscript~𝑟𝑡subscript𝐃test\tilde{rt}^{\mathbf{D}_{\mathrm{test}}} equals r​t𝐃test𝑟superscript𝑡subscript𝐃testrt^{\mathbf{D}_{\mathrm{test}}}, with the latter being stored in the EVM. Since 𝐃testsubscript𝐃test\mathbf{D}_{\mathrm{test}} is publicly available, all clients can easily check its standardization, such that checking r​t~𝐃test=r​t𝐃testsuperscript~𝑟𝑡subscript𝐃test𝑟superscript𝑡subscript𝐃test\tilde{rt}^{\mathbf{D}_{\mathrm{test}}}=rt^{\mathbf{D}_{\mathrm{test}}} is sufficient. This approach allows the system to guarantee truthful submissions of c𝑐c without having to store 𝐃testsubscript𝐃test\mathbf{D}_{\mathrm{test}} onchain, which would, depending on k𝑘k and ntestsubscript𝑛testn_{\mathrm{test}} be costly and challenging. A detailed implementation of πcsuperscript𝜋𝑐\pi^{c} is again included in Section 3.2.

3.1.4 Compute Incentives

To translate C=(c1,…,c|I|)⊺𝐶superscriptsubscript𝑐1…subscript𝑐𝐼⊺C=(c_{1},\dots,c_{|I|})^{\intercal} transparently into each client’s incentive payment visubscript𝑣𝑖v_{i}, we choose an efficient approach that can be computed on-chain by the Clients smart contract. First, we normalize all submitted and validated cisubscript𝑐𝑖c_{i}’s to a vector Cnorm∈ℝ|I|subscript𝐶normsuperscriptℝ𝐼C_{\mathrm{norm}}\in\mathbb{R}^{|I|} that has expectation value μ=0𝜇0\mu=0 and the standard deviation σ=1𝜎1\sigma=1. We multiply all entries in Cnormsubscript𝐶normC_{\mathrm{norm}} with (−1)1(-1) as lower cisubscript𝑐𝑖c_{i} implies higher model performance and, subsequently, replace negative entries with 00 (i.e., ensure that all cnorm,isubscript𝑐norm𝑖c_{\mathrm{norm,}i} that are higher than the mean of all cisubscript𝑐𝑖c_{i} are not incentivized). Next, we scale the data such that ∑i=0|I|cnorm,i=1superscriptsubscript𝑖0𝐼subscript𝑐norm𝑖1\sum\limits_{i=0}^{|I|}c_{\mathrm{norm},i}=1. Upon entry, clients have to pay an admission fee B𝐵B, such that we can distribute the incentive payments V=(v1,…,v|I|)⊺∈ℝ+𝑉superscriptsubscript𝑣1…subscript𝑣𝐼⊺superscriptℝV=(v_{1},\dots,v_{|I|})^{\intercal}\in\mathbb{R}^{+} as follows:

V=B⋅|Ivalid|⋅Cnorm𝑉⋅𝐵subscript𝐼validsubscript𝐶norm\displaystyle V=B\cdot|I_{\mathrm{valid}}|\cdot C_{\mathrm{norm}} (26)

where |Ivalid|subscript𝐼valid|I_{\mathrm{valid}}| is the number of clients with valid wi′subscriptsuperscript𝑤′𝑖w^{\prime}_{i} and cisubscript𝑐𝑖c_{i}. The payments are distributed by the function reward_clients() which can only be executed by the client who has initially deployed the Clients smart contract. Moreover, by using Solidity’s mapping, every client (i.e., address) can only register once as the data would be overwritten when joining multiple times and a new clientID would be set. We summarize the system outlined above in Table 2.

3.2 Implementation

In this section, we describe the implementation of our architecture. Please note that, following circom terminology and in contrast to Section 3.1, we will now refer to single ‘circuits’ that are callable with input and output signals as ‘templates’, whereas we refer to a set of ‘templates’ that make up a ZKP as ‘circuits’. ‘Signals’ (signal) are the basis for defining constraints (using ===) and can only be assigned a value once (using <-- or -->). Both <== and ==> declare a constraint and assign a signal’s value at the same time. On the other hand, circom also includes conventional variables (var). As we use snarkjs and hence a framework for proof creation and verification based on SNARKs, a so-called trusted setup is required initially. It consists of two phases, one of which is independent of the circuit (‘powers of tau’111The ‘powers of tau’ ceremony, also referred to as ‘phase 1 trusted setup’, is a circuit-agnostic MPC ceremony where multiple independent parties collaboratively construct common parameters from their secret random values. The parameters allow to obtain a proving and a verification key in a later stage. Note that the SNARK protocol’s integrity guarantee (“soundness”) is compromised if all parties’ random values are exposed. It is, however, important to note that while information about the private inputs to the MPC would allow to create fake proofs and hence to violate the integrity of our artifact, the privacy of the participants’ data would still be ensured even in this case [71].) and that we could just import, as well as one that is circuit-specific. For implementation purposes, we conducted the trusted setup alone. However, for practical applications, a group of trusted parties would need to conduct an MPC such that the participants in the FL system would be confident that at least one group member deleted their input to the MPC.

We will include several, truncated source code excerpts throughout the following section. Please find the whole project on GitHub222github.com/timon131/ma_webstorm_v4. Note that some templates are taken from iden3’s circomlib.

3.2.1 Weight Proof πwsuperscript𝜋𝑤\pi^{w}

We start by explaining the implementation of πwsuperscript𝜋𝑤\pi^{w}’s circuit, namely LinRegParams(...). First, we define the private and public inputs according to (24). The main template execution requires various variables (cf. listing 1), some of which are also input signals to the circuit for circom-specific reasons. Providing an untruthful value for some of these variables might make adversarial attacks possible. To make sure that these critical input variables are correct, the circuit requires the respective values as input signals to check equality. Listing 2 provides an overview of the implementation of πwsuperscript𝜋𝑤\pi^{w}. The circuit as the basis for the ZKP is structured into five parts:

  • •

    Step 1 – Range proofs for εμsubscript𝜀𝜇\varepsilon_{\mu} and εσsubscript𝜀𝜎\varepsilon_{\sigma}:
    To ensure that 𝐃𝐃\mathbf{D}’s mean μ≈0𝜇0\mu\approx 0 and variance σ≈1𝜎1\sigma\approx 1, a certain accuracy is set by εμsubscript𝜀𝜇\varepsilon_{\mu} and εσsubscript𝜀𝜎\varepsilon_{\sigma} respectively. Based on both values, LinRegParams checks the accuracy of all μ𝜇\mu and σ𝜎\sigma for X1,…,Xksubscript𝑋1…subscript𝑋𝑘X_{1},\ldots,X_{k} and Y𝑌Y. For example, setting in_require_meanxn_acc =3absent3=3 would require that the absolute value of every μ⋅n⋅𝜇𝑛\mu\>\cdot\>n is smaller than εμ=10−3subscript𝜀𝜇superscript103\varepsilon_{\mu}=10^{-3} (taking into account the conversion in (8) using d𝑑d). Analogously, in_require_varxn sets the upper bound for σ⋅n⋅𝜎𝑛\sigma\>\cdot\>n via εσsubscript𝜀𝜎\varepsilon_{\sigma}.

  • •

    Step 2 – Check r​t𝐃𝑟superscript𝑡𝐃rt^{\mathbf{D}}:
    This step rebuilds 𝐃𝐃\mathbf{D}’s Merkle tree with one data point (a prime field element as matrix entry) at each leaf. To improve the system’s performance, we do not hash the particular leaves on the lowest level since hashing is costly. This works because the hashing algorithm operates on big numbers that can be sufficiently large to cover any prime field element. After computing the tree, the template ensures that the computed root equals the public input r​t𝐃𝑟superscript𝑡𝐃rt^{\mathbf{D}}, which will be compared to the commitment specified at registration when calling the smart contract’s method Clients.

  • •

    Steps 3 and 6 – Range proofs for εinversesubscript𝜀inverse\varepsilon_{\mathrm{inverse}} and εw′subscript𝜀superscript𝑤′\varepsilon_{w^{\prime}}:
    To verify the upper bound on εinversesubscript𝜀inverse\varepsilon_{\mathrm{inverse}}, the template checks the proximity of every entry in ((𝐗⊺​𝐗)​𝐙−𝟙)superscript𝐗⊺𝐗𝐙1\left((\mathbf{X}^{\intercal}\mathbf{X})\mathbf{Z}-\mathbbm{1}\right) to 00. For example, setting in_require_XX_acc =3absent3=3 would require that the absolute value of every entry is smaller than εinverse=10−3subscript𝜀inversesuperscript103\varepsilon_{\mathrm{inverse}}=10^{-3} (again taking into account the conversion in (8) using d𝑑d). The same applies to in_require_b_noisy_acc, εw′subscript𝜀superscript𝑤′\varepsilon_{w^{\prime}}, and w′−w~′superscript𝑤′superscript~𝑤′w^{\prime}-\tilde{w}^{\prime}.

  • •

    Steps 4 and 5 – Range proofs for ϑ𝐙subscriptitalic-ϑ𝐙\vartheta_{\mathbf{Z}} and ϑ𝐗⊺​Ysubscriptitalic-ϑsuperscript𝐗⊺𝑌\vartheta_{\mathbf{X}^{\intercal}Y}
    Both ϑ𝐙subscriptitalic-ϑ𝐙\vartheta_{\mathbf{Z}} and ϑ𝐗⊺​Ysubscriptitalic-ϑsuperscript𝐗⊺𝑌\vartheta_{\mathbf{X}^{\intercal}Y} must be provided as inputs to the template in absolute numbers. The main template first finds the largest (by absolute value) entry in the matrix or vector using the maximum norm:

    ∥𝐀∥=k⋅maxs,t⁡|as,t|delimited-∥∥𝐀⋅𝑘subscript𝑠𝑡subscript𝑎𝑠𝑡\displaystyle\lVert\mathbf{A}\rVert=k\cdot\max\limits_{s,t}|a_{s,t}| (27)

    where 𝐀𝐀\mathbf{A} can be either 𝐙∈ℕ(k+1)×(k+1)𝐙superscriptℕ𝑘1𝑘1\mathbf{Z}\in\mathbb{N}^{\left(k+1\right)\times\left(k+1\right)} or 𝐗⊺​𝐘∈ℕk+1superscript𝐗⊺𝐘superscriptℕ𝑘1\mathbf{\mathbf{X}^{\intercal}Y}\in\mathbb{N}^{k+1}. Then it checks whether 0≤∥𝐀∥≤ϑ𝐀0delimited-∥∥𝐀subscriptitalic-ϑ𝐀0\leq\lVert\mathbf{A}\rVert\leq\vartheta_{\mathbf{A}} holds for both choices of 𝐀𝐀\mathbf{A}.

Note that along with these six steps, the template performs the computation of w′superscript𝑤′w^{\prime} iteratively. The LDP noise is added in the last step by generating hjsubscriptℎ𝑗h_{j} using (20), choosing the respective LDP noise q𝑞q from L𝐿L using (19) and (21), as well as adding q𝑞q as in (17).

3.2.2 Cost Proof πcsuperscript𝜋𝑐\pi^{c}

Next, we outline the implementation of πcsuperscript𝜋𝑐\pi^{c} in our proposed system, for which LinRegCost(...) is the main template. πcsuperscript𝜋𝑐\pi^{c}’s private inputs (cf. lines 3 to 10 in Listing 3) resemble those of πwsuperscript𝜋𝑤\pi^{w} except for w+superscript𝑤w^{+} and Sign​(wi)Signsubscript𝑤𝑖\mathrm{Sign}(w_{i}), which are required to reproduce c𝑐c as outlined in Section 3.1.3. Note that the inputs of 𝐃testsubscript𝐃test\mathbf{D}_{\mathrm{test}} in lines 12 to 15 of Figure 3 are declared as private signals due to performance reasons (cf. Section 4 for details), even though they are publicly available. Also πcsuperscript𝜋𝑐\pi^{c} consists of five major steps to make sure that clients compute and submit their cost c𝑐c truthfully (cf. Listing 4):

  • •

    Steps 1 and 2 – Check r​t𝐃𝑟superscript𝑡𝐃rt^{\mathbf{D}} and r​t𝐃test𝑟superscript𝑡subscript𝐃testrt^{\mathbf{D}_{\mathrm{test}}}:
    In addition to checking the Merkle tree root r​t𝐃𝑟superscript𝑡𝐃rt^{\mathbf{D}} (as in LinRegProof(...)), πcsuperscript𝜋𝑐\pi^{c} also ensures that clients calculate their c𝑐c based on the test data set 𝐃test=(𝐗test​Ytest)subscript𝐃testsubscript𝐗testsubscript𝑌test\mathbf{D}_{\mathrm{test}}=\left(\mathbf{X}_{\mathrm{test}}~{}Y_{\mathrm{test}}\right) by requiring r​t~𝐃test=r​t𝐃testsuperscript~𝑟𝑡subscript𝐃test𝑟superscript𝑡subscript𝐃test\tilde{rt}^{\mathbf{D}_{\mathrm{test}}}=rt^{\mathbf{D}_{\mathrm{test}}}. 𝐃testsubscript𝐃test\mathbf{D}_{\mathrm{test}} is a standardized, publicly available, and central data set that is made available to all clients through a cloud service. Besides, 𝐃𝐃\mathbf{D}’s standardization does not need to be checked again, as πwsuperscript𝜋𝑤\pi^{w} already ensures its standardization and πcsuperscript𝜋𝑐\pi^{c} verifies that r​t~𝐃superscript~𝑟𝑡𝐃\tilde{rt}^{\mathbf{D}} equals r​t𝐃𝑟superscript𝑡𝐃rt^{\mathbf{D}}.

  • •

    Step 3 – Range proof for εwsubscript𝜀𝑤\varepsilon_{w}:
    Similar to step 5 in LinRegProof(...), we allow controlling ∥w−w~∥delimited-∥∥𝑤~𝑤\lVert w-\tilde{w}\rVert by performing a range proof using the input εwsubscript𝜀𝑤\varepsilon_{w}. This means that essentially, the computation of the unperturbed weight w~~𝑤\tilde{w} is repeated and, subsequently, its proximity to w𝑤w is checked analogous to πwsuperscript𝜋𝑤\pi^{w}’s range proof for εw′subscript𝜀superscript𝑤′\varepsilon_{w^{\prime}}.

  • •

    Steps 4 and 5 – Check c𝑐c:
    First, as in (25), step 4 estimates Y^testsubscript^𝑌test\hat{Y}_{\mathrm{test}}. Second, step 5 derives c~~𝑐\tilde{c} and ensures that c~~𝑐\tilde{c} equals the submitted c𝑐c.

3.2.3 Smart Contract

After introducing LinRegProof(...) and LinRegCost(...), this section provides an overview of the governance structure implied by the main smart contract, namely Clients. To reduce Clients’s size, we implemented lib as a support library. lib defines all structs required by Clients (cf. Listing 5) and repeatedly used methods like, e.g., proof verification calls. We will briefly introduce both major structs FL_client and FL_generic:

  • •

    FL_generic: Contains all global variables for, e.g., defining k𝑘k, n𝑛n, r​t𝐃test𝑟superscript𝑡subscript𝐃testrt^{\mathbf{D}_{\mathrm{test}}}, L𝐿L, or the variables to control the range proofs. The client that initially deploys the Clients smart contract must instantiate fl_generic, which will be the only global instance of the struct.

  • •

    FL_client: Upon registering, all clients are assigned to an instance fl_client (implemented via a mapping mapclient from the particular client’s address to the respective instance fl_client). FL_client includes all client-specific data as, for example, wi′subscriptsuperscript𝑤′𝑖w^{\prime}_{i}, r​ti𝐃𝑟subscriptsuperscript𝑡𝐃𝑖rt^{\mathbf{D}}_{i}, and both proofs.

To register, clients call the smart contract’s registerClient(...) function. As depicted in Listing 6, calling registerClient(...) requires r​ti𝐃𝑟subscriptsuperscript𝑡𝐃𝑖rt^{\mathbf{D}}_{i} as input, since clients must commit to their data set 𝐃isubscript𝐃𝑖\mathbf{D}_{i} upon joining the system. Further, they have to pay the admission fee B𝐵B defined in fl_generic which will be used to distribute the incentive payments later. Moreover, a clientID, a mapping mapID to connect the clients’ addresses with their clientID, and the current block hash (at the time of registering) serving as source of public randomness for deriving their LDP noise p𝑝p will be set automatically.

Subsequently, clients can upload their wi′subscriptsuperscript𝑤′𝑖w^{\prime}_{i} by calling the function uploadBeta(...) and delivering the following inputs:

  • •

    t_betaverifier: Address of the deployed weight verifier contract. The client must deploy this contract before calling uploadBeta(...) and provide the respective address such that other clients and uploadBeta(...) itself can verify the client’s weight proof.

  • •

    betaproof: This struct (cf. Listing 5) contains the actual proof, which is also the first part of the call data for verifying the weight proof.

  • •

    beta_noisy_true is the struct containing the submitted wi′subscriptsuperscript𝑤′𝑖w^{\prime}_{i}.

uploadBeta(...) will collect the respective public inputs (cf. Listing 1) and, together with the provided betaproof, verify the proof πwsuperscript𝜋𝑤\pi^{w} onchain. Successfully verifying the proof requires correct input data DisubscriptD𝑖\mathrm{D}_{i}, the correct approximate inverse ZZ\mathrm{Z} (accuracy controlled by d𝑑d), and correct computation of wi′subscriptsuperscript𝑤′𝑖w^{\prime}_{i}. If successful, uploadBeta(...) saves the submitted beta (i.e., the client’s wi′subscriptsuperscript𝑤′𝑖w^{\prime}_{i}), sets the client’s betaproof_valid to true, and updates betaglobal (i.e., wgsubscript𝑤𝑔w_{g}). The procedure is analogous (except for updating betaglobal) when submitting the cost cisubscript𝑐𝑖c_{i} by calling uploadCost(...), such that we will not further describe the function.

Eventually, to trigger the distribution of incentive payments, only the initial client t_initialclient can call the function Incentivize_clients(...). Incentivize_clients(...) will calculate the incentive payments V𝑉V and distribute them to those clients, who have successfully submitted their wi′subscriptsuperscript𝑤′𝑖w^{\prime}_{i}, according to their contribution as described in Section 3.1.4. However, as this requires trust in the initial client (as only she/he can prompt the incentive payment by calling Incentivize_clients(...)), this way of triggering the payoff is probably not suitable in all scenarios. To make the trigger more trustless, the initial client could also specify ways to prompt the payoff. For example, any client could trigger it as soon as a certain threshold of participants is reached, or a certain amount of time (measured in the block number) has passed.

4 Evaluation

To evaluate our system, we ran several tests with different parameters. k𝑘k and n𝑛n are mainly influencing the complexity of our system, since they determine the number of Merkle tree leaves and, thus, the number of hashes that we compute in a SNARK. Note that more specifically, (k+1)⋅n⋅𝑘1𝑛(k+1)\,\cdot\,n for πwsuperscript𝜋𝑤\pi^{w} and (k+1)⋅(n+ntest)⋅𝑘1𝑛subscript𝑛test(k+1)\,\cdot\,(n+n_{\mathrm{test}}) for πcsuperscript𝜋𝑐\pi^{c} determines the number of leaves since we leave out X0,i=(1,…,1)subscript𝑋0𝑖1…1X_{0,i}=(1,\ldots,1) and instead only hash X1,i,…,Xk,isubscript𝑋1𝑖…subscript𝑋𝑘𝑖X_{1,i},\ldots,X_{k,i} as well as Yisubscript𝑌𝑖Y_{i}. Besides the number of leaves, also the choice of the hashing function can have a significant impact on the system performance. For example, when switching from ‘Poseidon’ [72] to ‘MiMC’ [73] hashing, the number of constraints of our system roughly increases by a factor 444. Since this factor remains approximately the same when increasing circuit complexity (i.e., the number of constraints), we tested our artifact only with ‘Poseidon’ hashes on an AWS instance (Ubuntu 20.04, 16 virtual CPU cores, and 64 GB RAM). Instead of snarkjs’ default web assembly compiler, we used a native compiler333snarkit by Fluidex (C++) that can handle larger circuits.

Table 3 provides an excerpt of our test results (Tables 4 and 5 in the appendix contain the entire test data for πwsuperscript𝜋𝑤\pi^{w} and πcsuperscript𝜋𝑐\pi^{c} respectively). Note that we used rapidsnark to generate the proofs (cf. “proof gen duration”). Besides, due to their similar implementation (cf. Section 3.2), the cost proof’s performance test results do not differ significantly from the weight proof’s results. We will, therefore, mainly focus on the weight proof’s results:

Before analyzing our system’s performance, we describe an essential optimization that prior tests suggested: We found that the recomputations of the Merkle trees are the artifact’s dominating operations in terms of constraints. Therefore, we optimized the computation of r​t𝐃𝑟superscript𝑡𝐃rt^{\mathbf{D}} and r​t𝐃test𝑟superscript𝑡subscript𝐃testrt^{\mathbf{D}_{\mathrm{test}}} by hashing six instead of two data points at the leaf level at once and hard-coding ‘empty’ leaf hashes to avoid additional hashing in those Merkle trees that are not entirely filled with data points on the leaf level (depending on k𝑘k, n𝑛n, and ntestsubscript𝑛testn_{\mathrm{test}}, not every leaf necessarily represents a data point as the bottom level must – given our Merkle tree optimization – always contain 2depth⋅ 3⋅superscript2depth32^{\,\mathrm{depth}}\,\cdot\,3 leaves). This optimization reduced the circuit complexity by roughly 50%. Then, computing the circuit-specific trusted setup for a LR on a training data set with k=4𝑘4k=4 features and sample size n=1,000𝑛1000n=1,000 per client in a FL setting takes roughly 232323 minutes each for πwsuperscript𝜋𝑤\pi^{w} (cf. Table 3) and πcsuperscript𝜋𝑐\pi^{c} (cf. Table 5 in the appendix). Note that, as outlined above, the circuit-specific trusted setup must only be computed once and can then be used by all clients for a particular FL learning task. Using the proving key from the trusted setup, every client must spend roughly 2.52.52.5 minutes on computing both proofs that allow fellow clients to verify their submitted weight w𝑤w and cost c𝑐c (for k=4𝑘4k=4 and n=1,000𝑛1000n=1,000). In practical FL applications, the proof generation likely runs on less sophisticated machines than our AWS instance. We, therefore, also tested the proof duration on a single CPU core (also for combinations other than k=4𝑘4k=4 and n=1,000𝑛1000n=1,000). The results reveal that the witness generation duration was not sensitive to this limitation, whereas the duration for generating the proof using rapidsnark increased seven times from 4.34.34.3 to 29.429.429.4 seconds and the proof verification duration four times from 0.240.240.24 to 0.970.970.97 seconds. In total, the proof duration grew 1.41.41.4 times from around 757575 to 103103103 seconds. Moreover, the RAM required to generate and validate proofs remains below 4 GB and agnostic to the number of constraints. Looking at the performance of the system’s smart contract on the EVM, we find gas cost of around 2.22.22.2 million for all πwsuperscript𝜋𝑤\pi^{w}-related on-chain operations and 920,000920000920,000 for all πcsuperscript𝜋𝑐\pi^{c}-related operations. This translates into a total of roughly USD 127012701270 for all on-chain operations (USD 900900900 for πwsuperscript𝜋𝑤\pi^{w} operations and USD 370370370 for πcsuperscript𝜋𝑐\pi^{c} operations) per client, given a gas price of 100 gwei and a rate of 1 ETH = USD 4,000. While in absolute terms this is prohibitively expensive, it is only 21%percent2121\% of the current public Ethereum target block capacity as well as 10.5%percent10.510.5\% of the block limit. Note that the πcsuperscript𝜋𝑐\pi^{c} operations are significantly cheaper than the πwsuperscript𝜋𝑤\pi^{w} operations, mainly since the latter requires the vector L𝐿L as public input and updates wgsubscript𝑤gw_{\mathrm{g}}. As long as operations on public blockchains are that costly, using a permissioned blockchain like Quorum can allow not only to reduce costs but also allowing for considerably higher throughput [74].

To assess our system’s scalability, we focus on analyzing the impacts of increasing k𝑘k, n𝑛n, and ntestsubscript𝑛testn_{\mathrm{test}} on the circuit-specific trusted setup, the proof generation and verification, as well as the gas cost of the smart contract. Both Figure 2 and Table 3 show results that are in line with the expected scaling properties of SNARKs: The computation of the circuit-specific trusted setups (i.e., ‘key gen duration’) as well as the time it takes to generate the proofs (i.e., ‘proof duration’) scale linearly with (k+1)⋅n⋅𝑘1𝑛(k+1)\,\cdot\,n or (k+1)⋅(n+ntest)⋅𝑘1𝑛subscript𝑛test(k+1)\,\cdot\,(n+n_{\mathrm{test}}) (cf. Table 5 in the appendix). Moreover, verification duration, verification key size, and proof size do not significantly change when increasing the circuit complexity. Thus, increasing k𝑘k, n𝑛n, or ntestsubscript𝑛testn_{\mathrm{test}} will have only minor effects on the system’s overall computation effort, since the proof duration might grow for an individual client whilst the redundant on-chain proof storage and verification cost will remain constant. Even when translating our results to circuits as huge as those in the Hermez project (the project also used circom with snarkjs and manages to compute a proof for around 100100100 million constraints in few minutes on a server with 64 virtual cores and 1 TB RAM [75]), we find promising scaling performance: Given the test results, we expect that πwsuperscript𝜋𝑤\pi^{w} and πcsuperscript𝜋𝑐\pi^{c} with (k+1)⋅n=600,000⋅𝑘1𝑛600000(k+1)\,\cdot\,n=600,000 data points and ntest=0.1⋅n=6,000formulae-sequencesubscript𝑛test⋅0.1𝑛6000n_{\mathrm{test}}=0.1\,\cdot\,n=6,000 would result in roughly 100100100 million constraints and hence be feasible to prove in a few minutes to hours per proof (depending on the hardware used; in our setup roughly 2.52.52.5 hours with 16 CPU cores or approximately 3.53.53.5 hours with one core) whilst handling a huge sample size (e.g., k=5𝑘5k=5 and n=100,000𝑛100000n=100,000). In this case, the one-time trusted setups would take a few hours to a few days for each participant of the trusted setup (which we assume will not necessarily be conducted by the clients in practice, but a small to medium-sized group or maybe also research institutions, as could be observed for the trusted setup used in Z-Cash, zkSync, etc.). Besides, we expect the verification duration, verification key size, and proof size to remain constant in this scenario.

Also, the gas cost for the EVM operations is independent of the proof complexity. The only data that must be stored on-chain to verify a proof are the proof itself, the verification key, and the public inputs. Both the proof size as well as the verification key size are constant for every k𝑘k, n𝑛n, and ntestsubscript𝑛testn_{\mathrm{test}}. The public inputs’ volume only increases when either the number of features k𝑘k or the LDP noise discretization interval dℒsubscript𝑑ℒd_{\mathcal{L}} grows, since this leads to an increase in the number of entries in the weight vector w′superscript𝑤′w^{\prime} or the LDP noise vector L𝐿L. Thus, raising w′superscript𝑤′w^{\prime} or L𝐿L increases the payload size, which in turn leads to a rise in gas cost. However, for moderate k𝑘k and dℒsubscript𝑑ℒd_{\mathcal{L}}, the total gas cost remains small since the respective proof verification itself is responsible for the major part of the gas cost. Therefore, both proofs can be stored as well as verified cheaply on-chain also for large circuits and the particular gas cost remains, as mentioned above, approximately at 2.22.22.2 million for all πwsuperscript𝜋𝑤\pi^{w}-related on-chain operations and 920,000920000920,000 for all πcsuperscript𝜋𝑐\pi^{c}-related operations. Eventually, a clients’ effort does not grow with the size of other clients’ underlying data sets or the number of participating clients. Further, the number of on-chain transactions only grows linearly with the number of clients and is independent of the size of the clients’ training data as well as the central test data. These results promise high potential also for more sophisticated ML applications that require higher data volumes.

Eventually, we refrain from testing the accuracy of our FL system. The only difference regarding accuracy between our and a plain FL system is the LDP noise that we add to the clients’ weights; and since aggregation is an average over all local weights plus noise, this difference is just an average of i.i.d. Laplacian-distributed random variables, which has mean 00 and standard deviation proportional to ε|I|𝜀𝐼\frac{\varepsilon}{\sqrt{\lvert I\rvert}}. The value of ε𝜀\varepsilon and |I|𝐼\lvert I\rvert hence completely determine the change in accuracy of our approach compared to the literature.

5 Discussion and Conclusion

Our paper aims at answering the research question of how a FL system can achieve fairness, integrity, and privacy simultaneously whilst still being practical and scalable. After identifying a business need for these requirements and arguing that related work so far has not proposed an architecture that satisfies them, we described our proposed system in Section 3 based on a combination of blockchain, ZKP, and LDP. Our conceptual discussion of the architecture and the experiments that we describe in Section 4 suggest that our implementation indeed offers a practical solution to confidential, fair, and tamper-resistant FL that achieves reasonable performance and scalability properties for LRs. Next to suggesting a pathway to effectively combining FL with blockchain, ZKP, and LDP, we develop a system that allows clients to verifying that other clients truthfully trained their local model and received a fair compensation for participating in the case of LR. Thus, we go beyond existing research that has suggested ZKPs for verifying ML model inference based on already trained models.

However, our research is not without limitations and reveals potential for future research that we will outline in this section to conclude our paper. First, even though our suggested system does currently only support LRs, we tried to design it as generic as possible to allow for adapting the system to other classes of ML protocols. Specifically, we move computationally intensive parts (in our case, the inversion of 𝐗⊺​𝐗superscript𝐗⊺𝐗\mathbf{X}^{\intercal}\mathbf{X}) outside the circuit and only check certain properties of the result (in our case, that the approximate inverse that must be provided as private input to the ZKP is indeed close to the true inverse, cf. Section 3.1.1) rather than recomputing the result. For the case of LR, we derived an error bound (see (16)) that allowed us to significantly reduce the complexity of the respective circuit while maintaining full tamper resistance. The approach of only proving specific properties that the local weights need to satisfy to indicate the integrity of training may be generalizable to further classes of ML models, also considering the recent advancement in using ZKPs for frequent operations in ML (e.g., [65]). Since training ML models often involves solving a convex optimization problem where optimality can be checked locally (e.g., all partial derivatives in the allowed directions are 00) [76], we encourage future research to adapt the suggested architecture to more sophisticated classes of ML models beyond LR. Furthermore, the aggregation of weights in federated learning is often linear [25], so our concept of perturbing the local weights with verifiable noise is applicable beyond multiple LRs: Assuming that the training data is i.i.d. (a common assumption in FL applications), the local weights are also i.i.d.. Moreover, as we construct the clients’ LDP noise from a random oracle, the noise is also i.i.d. and has mean 00 and finite variance by construction. Since the weights and the noise applied to them are by construction independent, by the linearity of the averaging algorithm FedAvg, the error in the global model is a weighted average of local noise and the random variable (noise times weight) is i.i.d. with expectation value 00 and finite variance. By the law of large numbers, the error in the aggregated global model hence converges to 00. Thus, for a large number of clients, the error term in the aggregate model as introduced by LDP is typically small. It follows that our approach of using LDP (which has been proposed by several other scholars but is particularly relevant in our system because we can prove not only the correct training but also the correct addition of noise) extends to more sophisticated ML models beyond LR.

To further improve the performance and practicality of our system, we aim at implementing the ZKPs via STARKs for improved proof creation performance, post-quantum security, and eliminating the need for a trusted setup in the future. Further, the system’s scalability would further benefit from a recursive verification mechanism that reduces the complexity of verifying weight and cost proofs. This could be implemented by building on batching techniques [77] or recursive proofs [78, 79] and would facilitate scalability by hierarchical aggregation (e.g., only log⁡(|I|)𝐼\log(\lvert I\rvert) verification steps would be required on-chain). Besides, even though recalculating w𝑤w in πcsuperscript𝜋𝑐\pi^{c} is not the proof’s main complexity driver, we see optimization potential there: One could commit a hash of the weight (without noise) and some random salt in the smart contract (proving that the hash was computed like that), so for computing the costs we only need to prove that we used the pre-image of this hash (without salt) for the computation. This can further reduce the cost proof’s number of constraints. Next to optimizations of our own code and the performance improvements in libraries that support the generation of ZKP (e.g., STARKs or circom 2.0), we are also confident that hardware acceleration for faster ZKP-related operations and particularly proving will be available soon, as research in this area is already conducted, e.g., by projects that build on Ethereum and that leverage ZKPs [80]. This may allow getting even shorter proof times also on devices that are computationally more restricted than a Laptop.

Moreover, we acknowledge that there are still some attacks on integrity: When clients know the learning task (i.e., in our case, the parameters stored on fl_generic) prior to committing their data when joining the system, they could attack the system by manipulating their data set before committing to it. However, reverse engineering the data in order to get a desired (malicious) result for the weights is likely more effort than just contributing arbitrarily chosen weights. Moreover, we expect many use cases for our proposed system to be built on sensor data (e.g., from vehicular networks or health applications). Given this, and the availability of certified sensors (e.g., by means of a crypto-chip on the sensor and a certificate of the manufacturer), as are emerging, for example, in Germany’s Smart Meter rollout [81], the ZKP-based approach could handle this issue by including a proof of authenticity (i.e., a proof that the data was signed by a private key that is bound to a certificate that was in turn signed by a trusted, publicly known entity) for the sensor input data when committing to it. This would be easy to integrate at the costs of an additional signature verification per Merkle tree leaf (around 5,000 constraints per leaf for a Schnorr signature). This still does not protect against physical manipulation (imagine putting a temperature sensor to a place where it is not supposed to be), but may offer a reasonable degree of trust in data provenance in many practical scenarios.

Our current incentive mechanism relies on the existence of a central and public data set as described in Section 3.1.4. Since we acknowledge that this hypothesis is not always feasible in practice, we will work on developing other, effective incentive mechanisms. In doing so, we intend to ensure the mechanisms’ fairness by incorporating the research of Shapley [82]. In doing so, our construction allows us to perform the local evaluation of each client on their actual weights with and without noise, so we get new degrees of freedom for proving the correct evaluation and deriving fair incentives.

Lastly, to ensure the system’s applicability in practice, we plan a twofold approach. First, as we are currently training the test model on the California Housing Prices data set, we will also run accuracy tests to assess how our conceptual approach translates into data-related performance in practice. Second, we will evaluate the perspective of enterprises on the new features that the combination of FL with blockchain technology, LDP, and ZKP offers.

We believe that the convergence of emerging technologies like ML and blockchains in the context of data generated by the IoT, as Guggenberger et al. [83] or Singh et al. [84] suggest, combined with privacy-enhancing technologies in the context of sensor data sharing or derived models in data markets [51], has the potential to facilitate many new use cases as well as business models and can inspire the field of computer science. As all these aspects are relevant for FL, we are expecting interesting results that further extend our design to more complex models in the future.
